questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with cough, nasal discomfort and weight loss. He has a travel history to South America in the past. On examination, he is found to have ulcerative granulomas on his nasal and buccal mucosa. A microscopic examination of the lesion is shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: characteristic mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance on microscopy, the most probable diagnosis is Paracoccidioidomycosis. It is caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. Paracoccidioidomycosis Causative agent Thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. (Option C) Epidemiology Confined to South America, it is called South American blastomycosis. Route of transmission Inhalation of spores Clinical features Chronic granulomatous disease of the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs. Primary pulmonary infection spreads by the hematogenous route to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin and lymphatics. Ulcerative granulomas of the buccal, and nasal mucosa. Diagnosis In tissue: Yeast phase - large, globose or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell giving a mariner's wheel or pilot's wheel or Mickey Mouse appearance. Culture: Mycelial phase Treatment Itraconazole is the drug of choice Histoplasma (Option A): It causes histoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It can cause pulmonary and systemic infections. Microscopy shows small intra- and extracellular yeast cells. This option is incorrect. Blastomyces (Option B): It causes blastomycosis. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms and may disseminate to the skin, bones, and other organs. The yeast form of Blastomyces is typically large, thick-walled, and appears as single broad-based buds. This option is incorrect. Cryptococcus (Option D): It causes cryptococcosis, primarily in

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?

options.B: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
options.D: Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.explanation: symptoms, history of exposure to bamboo rats, and immunocompromised status due to AIDS, microscopy showing septate hyphae with branched conidiophores, the likely pathogen is Talaromyces marneffei . This fungus produces green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar when cultured on Sabouraud agar, which is a characteristic feature of this organism. Penicillium marneffei Characteristics Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei. Thermally dimorphic fungus Causes Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis) Epidemiology Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India. High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients. Reservoir Bamboo rat Route of transmission Inhalation of fungal spores No person-to-person transmission Clinical manifestations It affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Lung involvement is common. Increased risk of

questions.question: What microscopic features are not observed when examining cultures of Histoplasma capsulatum?
questions.explanation: samples or body fluids during microscopic examination and not in cultures. Microscopic examination of Yeast in histoplasmosis: Culture: Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show White, cottony growth Microscopy: From culture colonies: Mycelial growth with large thick-walled spherical spores with tuberculate (Tuberculate macroconidia) and smooth-walled oval microconidia (Options A, B & C ruled out) Stained smears of the specimens: Show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells (Option D)

questions.question: A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

options.A: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.
options.B: The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone
options.C: The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
options.D: It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.explanation: eukaryotic pathogen that exhibits characteristics of both fungi and protozoa, making it difficult to culture in laboratory settings. Rhinosporidiosis Chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi Primarily affects mucosal membranes of: (Option A ruled out) Nose Nasopharynx Conjunctiva Urethra Endemic in tropical and subtropical regions; associated with contaminated water exposure (Option D ruled out) Microbiology of Rhinosporidiosis Aspect Details Causative Agent Rhinosporidium seeberi - eukaryotic pathogen exhibiting features of fungi and protozoa; cannot be cultured in vitro (Option C) Pathogenesis Occurs via endospores infecting traumatized mucosal surfaces, leading to hyperplastic growths and rhinosporidial polyps Histopathology Presence of thick-walled sporangia (50-1000 µ m) filled with endospores (5-10 µ m ) Surrounding tissue shows hyperplasia and infiltration by inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells) The lack of eosinophilic infiltration distinguishes it from similar infections. Staining Techniques H&E: Identifies sporangia and inflammatory response PAS: Stains endospores positively GMS: Visualizes fungal elements Clinical Presentation Nasal Masses : Soft, fleshy lesions, pedunculated or flat Red or granular appearance with yellowish-white dots (mature sporangia) Symptoms : Nasal obstruction Epistaxis (nosebleeds) Discharge Diagnosis Histopathology : Definitive through examination of excised tissue showing characteristic sporangia and inflammation. Clinical History : Important to note exposure to stagnant water or endemic areas. Treatment Treatment Option Details Surgical Intervention Wide surgical excision of lesions. Cauterization of base is recommended to minimize recurrence. Adjunctive Therapy Postoperative Dapsone is used to prevent recurrence, though efficacy is controversial due to resistance. (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: A biopsy from a cutaneous lesion in a patient with suspected sporotrichosis is examined under a microscope. Which of the following findings would strongly support the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi. Explanation: Sporothrix schenckii in the yeast phase is often described as cigar-shaped, which helps differentiate it from other fungi. Sporotrichosis Causative agent Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii . Epidemiology Common in gardeners, forest workers , and manual labourers. Route of transmission Minor trauma or thorn prick. Clinical features Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules. Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels. Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like. Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges. Specimens Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material. Diagnosis Microscopy: KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon) Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells. (Option C) Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase. Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections. Treatment Medications: Itraconazole Terbinafine Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection Cryotherapy. Thick-walled spherules filled with endospores (Option A): It is characteristic of Coccidioides immitis, the causative agent of coccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect. Mariner’s wheel-shaped yeast cells (Option B): It is characteristic of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, which causes paracoccidioidomycosis. This option is incorrect. Broad-based budding yeast cells (Option D): It is characteristic of Blastomyces dermatitidis, the causative organism of blastomycosis. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the typical transmission route of Coccidioides immitis ?

options.D: Insect bite from an endemic vector

questions.explanation: transmitted through the inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores, especially in arid, dusty environments. Coccidioidomycosis Causative agent Thermally dimorphic fungus Coccidioides immitis . Route of transmission Inhalation of dust containing fungal arthrospores. (Option B) Clinical features Self-limited, flu-like fever ("valley fever" or "desert rheumatism") . Primary pulmonary infection. Severe cases: Less than 1% develop chronic disseminated disease (coccidioidal granuloma), which can be fatal. Diagnosis In tissue: Spherules with a thick, doubly refractile wall, filled with endospores. Culture: Mycelial phase with hyphae that fragment into arthrospores. Arthrospores are infective. Skin test: Positive delayed hypersensitivity with "coccidioidin." Treatment Mild cases: Fluconazole or itraconazole. Severe cases: Amphotericin B. Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 611, 612

Histopathology and (LPCB) mount of colonies grown in culture are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

A 40-year-old male from North America presents with cough, fever, and weight loss. Chest imaging shows focal consolidation in the lungs, and he has developed ulcerative skin lesions on his face as shown below. A skin biopsy is performed, and the sample is sent for GMS staining. An image of the GMS stain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Dimorphic fungi can evade the host immune system primarily through which of the following mechanisms?

options.B: Conversion to a yeast form in the host

questions.explanation: exist in mold form but convert to yeast form in the host (at 37°C). The yeast form is typically more resistant to phagocytosis and immune responses, allowing the fungi to survive and multiply in the host. Dimorphic Fungus Have the ability to convert between two specific morphologic forms, yeast and hyphae. Types: Thermally dimorphic fungi: Converts between hyphae (22–25°C) and yeast (37°C), based on the temperature Thermally dimorphic fungi infect humans and other mammals Conversion to yeast within healthy and immunocompromised mammalian hosts is essential for virulence (Option B) Eg. Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides immitis and posadasii, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and lutzii, Sporothrix schenckii, Talaromyces marneffei, Emmonsia spp., Lacazia loboi. Nonthermal dimorphic fungi: Typically infects plants dimorphic fungus.png" data-author="" data-hash="10188" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/UvujaelLftKr86JvtFT61744477430.png" /> Formation of biofilms (Option A): It is a common immune evasion mechanism for Candida, but is not a primary characteristic of dimorphic fungi. This option is incorrect. Production of endotoxins (Option C): Endotoxins are lipopolysaccharides found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, not in fungi. Dimorphic fungi do not produce endotoxins. This option is incorrect. Direct cell-to-cell transmission (Option D): Dimorphic fungi are primarily transmitted through inhalation of spores from the environment and then converted to the yeast form within the host, rather than spreading directly from cell to cell. This option is incorrect. Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 127, 593, 594 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5463121/ Candida albicans biofilms: development, regulation, and molecular mechanisms - PMC

The lesions are asymptomatic but have not resolved with moisturizers. An image of the Microscopic examination of skin scrapings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: presents as hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macular lesions, typically on the chest, back, or upper limbs. It is asymptomatic and diagnosed by finding yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments on microscopy. Tinea Versicolor (Pityriasis Versicolor) A superficial fungal infection of the stratum corneum (outer skin layer) Mostly asymptomatic but may lead to visible skin discolouration Prevalent in tropical climates, commonly affecting young adults Causative agent : Malassezia furfur (previously called Pityrosporum orbiculare ) Appearance : Presents as discrete or confluent macular lesions Affected areas show pigmentation

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon?

options.A: It is exclusively seen in functional infections
options.B: It is never associated with parasitic infestations
options.C: It can occur in both infectious and noninfectious conditions
options.D: It does not involve any immune cells

questions.explanation: Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon is seen in a variety of conditions, both infectious (fungal, bacterial, or parasitic infections) and noninfectious (Hypereosinophilic syndrome and allergic conjunctival granulomas). Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) involves microorganisms or inert substances surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material Microscopically , it appears as strongly eosinophilic, amorphous material with star-like or club-shaped formations. This phenomenon surrounds or is adjacent to the causative agent It is often accompanied by an inflammatory reaction rich in eosinophils, histiocytes, epithelioid cells, and giant cells (Option D ruled out) Conditions where the phenomenon is seen Fungal infections Sporotrichosis, pityrosporum folliculitis, Zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis blastomycosis. Bacterial infections Botryomycosis, nocardiosis actinomycosis. Parasitic infestations Orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis cutaneous larva migrans. Noninfective pathologies Hypereosinophilic syndrome allergic conjunctival granulomas. Reference: (PDF) Splendore–Hoeppli phenomenon

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic, painless nodule on his foot, which has progressively enlarged over the past year. Upon examination, he has draining sinuses with black grains in the exudate. Microscopic examination of the tissue reveals thick-walled grains and hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this condition?
questions.explanation: associated with eumycetoma and is characterized by the presence of thick-walled grains and hyphae in microscopic examination. Mycetoma (Madura Foot) Definition : Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates Types : Eumycetoma (fungal) Actinomycetoma (bacterial) Clinical Presentation Initial Lesion : Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years Progression : Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains Complications : Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage Microscopic Examination Type Causative Agents Microscopic Features Eumycetoma Madurella mycetomatis , (Option C) Curvularia lunata , Scedosporium spp. , Acremonium spp. Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white). Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils. Actinomycetoma Actinomadura madurae , Nocardia spp. (Options A & B ruled out) Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology. Diagnostic Techniques Biopsy and Culture : Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens. Culturing exudates for specific organism identification. Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections. Imaging Studies : X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases. Treatment Type Treatment Approach Eumycetoma Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates. Actinomycetoma Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention. Trichophyton rubrum (Option D): It is a foot fungus responsible for tinea pedis (athlete's foot). It does not produce the thick-walled grains characteristic of eumycetoma. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: Match the following: Column A (Infection category) Column B (Disease) a. Superficial (i) Dermatophytosis b. Subcutaneous (ii) White piedra c. Systemic (iii) Mycetoma d. Cutaneous (iv) Blastomycosis
questions.explanation: tissue affected: Category Diseases Superficial (localised to the stratum corneum) Pytriasis versicolor, Tinea nigra, white piedra, black piedra. Cutaneous Dermatophytosis, Candidosis of skin, nail and mucosa. Subcutaneous Mycetoma, Chromomycosis Sporothicosis, Phaeohyphomycosis Entomophthoromycoses. Deep or systemic (often endemic) Histoplasmosis, Coccidiodomycosis Blastomycosis, Paracoccidiodomycosis. Opportunistic Candidosis, Cryptococcosis Aspergillosis, Penicilliosis, Zygomycosis, Pneumocystis pneumonia. Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page: 599.

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding the use of Wood’s lamp in dermatology?

options.A: It is not useful for diagnosing scalp infections as hair blocks fluorescence
options.B: It is done in a bright room using ultraviolet light
options.C: Normal skin will fluoresce bright pink under Wood’s lamp
options.D: Microsporum infections commonly fluoresce bright greenish-yellow under Wood's lamp

questions.explanation: Wood's lamp lamp. Wood's lamp examination for detecting superficial fungal infections Procedure: It is done in a dark room using ultraviolet light on the area of interest (Option B ruled out) Findings: Normal skin does not glow under UV light (Option C ruled out) Infected skin will fluoresce under light Clinical significance: It helps detect fungal infections on the skin, or scalp (Option A ruled out) Microsporum infections glow bright greenish-yellow (Option D) Malassezia (Pityriasis versicolor) infections glow golden-yellow Tinea capitis will reveal areas of baldness. Infection Cause Color Tinea capitis Fungal Blue-green Tinea (Pityriasis) versicolor Fungal Yellowish green or orange Erythrasma Bacterial Red Vitiligo Cell death White Porphyria cutanea tarda Genetic or exposure Red-pink Pseudomonas infections Bacterial Green Reference: Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 601.

questions.question: A 28-year-old patient presents with hair loss and scalp lesions. A hair perforation test is performed to differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes . Which of the following statements about the hair perforation test is true?

options.C: Microscopically hair is examined with Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) stain
options.D: T. mentagrophytes exhibits surface erosion of the hair shaft.

questions.explanation: mentagrophytes causes a characteristic wedge-shaped appearance due to surface erosion of the hair shaft. Hair Perforation Test Purpose : Differentiate between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes . Procedure Place strands of human hair in a petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water. Autoclave the dish. Add sterile 10% yeast extract and fragments of the test fungus to the hair. Incubate at 25°C for 2-3 weeks. (Option A ruled out) Examine the hair microscopically with a lactophenol cotton blue-stained wet preparation. (Option C ruled out) Test Results If T. mentagrophytes is present: The hair shaft appears wedge-shaped due to surface erosion. (Option B ruled out) (Option D) Characteristics of Fungal Infections: Both T. rubrum and T. mentagrophytes cause ectothrix hair infections, where arthrospores form a sheath around the hair. T. rubrum is the most common dermatophyte in humans, often leading to chronic, treatment-resistant lesions. Identification Methods Method Description Macroscopic examination Assess the growth rate, texture, and colour on media Urea hydrolysis test Determines ability to hydrolyze urea Growth on polished rice or special media Tests the ability to grow in specific conditions Temperature tolerance test Assesses resistance to elevated temperatures Nutritional requirements test Checks requirements for specific amino acids and vitamin

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents with a pruritic rash in the groin area. Upon examination, the lesion is erythematous with raised borders and has a clear centre. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the anatomical classification of dermatophytosis?
questions.explanation: specifically affects the groin and perineum, characterized by erythema and raised borders. Classification of Dermatophytosis Anatomic Classification Dermatophytosis can be classified based on the affected anatomical site: Tinea pedis Image C" data-author="" data-hash="10136" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/1DRJ57u3V7TKsS5PkcNN1744473577.png" /> Clinical Type Description Tinea barbae Infection of the bearded areas of the face and neck (barber's itch). (Option A ruled out) Tinea capitis Infection of the scalp; variants include favus and kerion. (Option B ruled out) Tinea corporis Infection of smooth, non-hairy skin (Tinea glabrosa). (Option D ruled out) Tinea cruris Infection of the groin and perineum (jock itch). (Option C) Tinea imbricata Tropical variant of Tinea corporis with concentric scaly patches. Tinea manuum Infection of the hand. Tinea pedis Infection of the foot (athlete's foot). Tinea unguium Infection of the nails. Classification by Genus Genus Key Characteristics Microsporum Predominantly macroconidia; spindle-shaped, multicellular structures; infects hair and skin. Trichophyton More abundant microconidia in clusters; macroconidia are thin, and elongated; include species like T. rubrum which is common in humans. Infects hair, nails and skin. Epidermophyton Lacks microconidia; club-shaped, multicellular macroconidia; infects skin and nails but not hair. Features Trichophyton Microsporum Epidermophyton 1. Site of infection Hair, nail, and skin Hair and skin only Skin and nail only 2. Colony Powdery pigmented Cotton-like pigmented Powdery greenish yellow 3. Spores a. Microconidia Abundant Relatively scanty Absent b. Macroconidia Pencil or cylindrical-shaped Spindle-shaped Club or pear-shaped Types of Conidia Microconidia : Small, unicellular conidia. Macroconidia : Larger, multicellular, septate conidia. Classification by Habitat Dermatophytes are further classified by their natural habitats: Habitat Type Characteristics Examples Anthropophilic Primarily found in humans; causes mild, chronic lesions. T. rubrum , E. floccosum , M. audouinii Zoophilic Natural parasites of animals; cause severe inflammation but are treatable. T. verrucosum , M. canis Geophilic Found in soil; less pathogenic to humans. M. gypseum , T. ajelloi

questions.question: A 10-year-old child presents with hair loss and black dot tinea capitis. Microscopic examination of the hair reveals elongated hyphae within the hair shaft. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely condition the child has?

options.B: It is commonly associated with Microsporum canis
options.C: It typically involves Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum
options.D: The treatment of choice is typically 2 weeks

questions.explanation: Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum are the primary fungi responsible for endothrix infections, where the fungus penetrates the hair shaft, leading to less contagious forms of tinea capitis, such as black dot tinea capitis. This distinguishes them from Microsporum canis , which causes ectothrix infections characterized by superficial hair involvement and is more contagious. Hair perforation test: The hair perforation test is a diagnostic procedure used in dermatology to evaluate the presence of certain fungal infections, particularly Trichophyton species, which can cause scalp or skin conditions such as ringworm. This test assesses the ability of a hair to be penetrated or perforated by fungal elements, offering insight into whether a fungal infection may be affecting the hair Dermatophyte Infections: Endothrix vs. Ectothrix Endothrix Characteristics Invasion : Fungi invade and grow inside the hair shaft, with arthroconidia present within the hair; the cuticle remains intact. Common Species : Trichophyton tonsurans , Trichophyton violaceum (non-inflammatory tinea capitis). (Option C) Clinical Presentation : Presents as black dot tinea capitis; less contagious than ectothrix. Diagnosis Microscopy : Shows elongated hyphae within the hair. Trichoscopy : Features comma-shaped and corkscrew hairs. Treatment Antifungal Therapy : Griseofulvin; treatment duration: 6-12 weeks. (Option D ruled out) Ectothrix Characteristics Invasion : Fungi grow on the hair shaft surface, degrading the cuticle; hyphae and arthroconidia are on both the surface and inside the hair. Common Species : Microsporum canis (inflammatory tinea capitis). (Option B ruled out) Clinical Presentation : Appears as grey patch tinea capitis; spreads rapidly. Diagnosis Microscopy : Fungal structures on the hair shaft's exterior. Trichoscopy : Features perifollicular scaling. (Option A ruled out) Treatment Antifungal Therapy : Griseofulvin; treatment duration may be longer. The hair perforation test is a diagnostic tool used to differentiate dermatophyte species. questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with dark, hard nodules along his scalp hair, which he mistakenly believes to be lice nits. Upon microscopic examination, branched hyphae and arthrospores are observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation: characterized by dark nodules on scalp hair and the presence of branched hyphae and arthrospores upon microscopic examination. Piedra Infection Superficial fungal infection affecting hair shaft. Characterized by nodules. Two main types: Black Piedra and White Piedra. Black Piedra Aspect Details Etiology Caused by Piedraia hortae (dematiaceous fungus) (Option B). Characteristics Affects scalp hair; it is common in individuals with long hair and poor hygiene. Clinical Features Hard, black nodules that may resemble lice nits; complex structure of filamentous hyphae and spores; examined using KOH shows branched hyphae and arthrospores. Diagnosis Direct microscopic examination: Branched hyphae and arthrospores Culture: Sabouraud dextrose agar shows dark colonies. Treatment Antifungal shampoos or systemic antifungals; treatment efficacy may be compromised by nodules' compact nature. White Piedra Aspect Details Etiology Caused by Trichosporon species, commonly Trichosporon beigelli, Trichosporon inkin (Option A ruled out). Characteristics Affects facial, axillary, and pubic hair; typically asymptomatic. Clinical Features Whitish, loosely adherent nodules consisting of arthroconidia and blastoconidia. Diagnosis KOH examination and culture reveal yeast-like colonies. Treatment Topical antifungals such as ketoconazole shampoo. Mixed Piedra Rare condition involving both black and white piedra Presents with both dark and light nodules Requires careful mycological examination for accurate diagnosis Candida albicans (Option C) : Candida albicans do not cause superficial fungal infections of the hair shaft like piedra. Microscopy shows Candida yeast with pseudohyphae. This option is incorrect. Malassezia furfur (Option D) : Malassezia furfur do not cause piedra. It primarily affects the skin and is involved in conditions related to skin oiliness rather than hard nodules along the hair shaft. Microscopy shows yeast cells grouped in a “grape bunch” format with short, branched filaments or spaghetti and meatball appearance. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman from a tropical region presents with a brown, macular lesion on the palm of her hand. There is no itching or scaling. Microscopic examination of skin scrapings reveals brownish, branched, septate hyphae along with budding cells. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation: characterized by black or brown macular lesions on the palms, with microscopy showing brown septate hyphae and budding cells .
